front.question: To protect vital organs, the body compensates by directing blood flow away from organs that are more tolerant of low flow, such as:

choices: apply pressure to the brachial artery.
apply a tourniquet proximal to the wrist.
wrap the towel with pressure bandages.
front.question: A 20-year-old male has a large laceration to his wrist. He is holding a blood-soaked towel over the wound, but it continues to bleed rapidly. You should:
front.source: See Emergency Medical Care for Shock

cards.back: apply a tourniquet proximal to the wrist.

front.question: Hypovolemic shock caused by severe burns is the result of a loss of:

choices: hypoperfusion to the cells of the body.
temporary dysfunction of a major organ.
widespread constriction of the blood vessels.
front.question: Shock is the result of:

cards.back: hypoperfusion to the cells of the body.

front.question: Which of the following clinical signs is unique to anaphylactic shock?

choices: Sensitized people will experience less severe reactions upon subsequent exposure.
Anaphylactic shock occurs immediately after a person is sensitized to an allergen.
Subsequent exposure after sensitization often produces a more severe reaction.
Anaphylactic shock is caused by immune system failure due to a toxic exposure.
front.question: Which of the following statements regarding anaphylactic shock is correct?

cards.back: Subsequent exposure after sensitization often produces a more severe reaction.

front.question: All of the following conditions should make you suspect shock, EXCEPT:

choices: under complete control of the voluntary portion of the nervous system.
circular muscular walls that regulate blood flow through the capillaries.
responsible for constricting to compensate for decreased cell perfusion.
capable of dilating in order to increase perfusion to crucial body organs.
front.question: Capillary sphincters are:

cards.back: circular muscular walls that regulate blood flow through the capillaries.

front.question: Which of the following injuries would MOST likely cause obstructive shock?

choices: A 23-year-old restless male with cool, clammy skin and tachycardia
A 32-year-old male with anxiety and a systolic blood pressure of 110 mm Hg
A 28-year-old female with pale skin and rapid, shallow respirations
A 20-year-old female with absent radial pulses and dilated pupils
front.question: Which of the following patients is in decompensated shock?

cards.back: A 20-year-old female with absent radial pulses and dilated pupils

front.question: Clinical signs of compensated shock include all of the following, EXCEPT:

A 70-year-old female was recently discharged from the hospital following a total hip replacement. Today, she presents with restlessness, tachycardia, and a blood pressure of 90/64 mm Hg. Her skin is hot and moist. You should be MOST suspicious that she is experiencing:
Pulmonary edema and impaired ventilation occur during:
In an acute injury setting, neurogenic shock is commonly accompanied by:
One of the primary waste products of normal cellular metabolism that must be removed from the body by the lungs is:

choices: widespread dilation of the blood vessels causes blood to pool in the vascular beds.
temporary but severe vasodilation causes a decrease in blood supply to the brain.
an injury causes restriction of the heart muscle and impairs its pumping function.
severe bleeding causes tachycardia in order to distribute blood to the organs faster.
front.question: Distributive shock occurs when:

cards.back: widespread dilation of the blood vessels causes blood to pool in the vascular beds.

front.question: Cardiogenic shock may result from all of the following, EXCEPT:
Which of the following would MOST likely result in hemorrhagic shock?

choices: Decompression of the injured side of the chest
Positive-pressure ventilation with a bag-valve mask
front.question: Which of the following is the ONLY action that can prevent death from a tension pneumothorax?
front.source: See Emergency Medical Care for Shock

cards.back: Decompression of the injured side of the chest

choices: massive vasoconstriction occurs distal to a spinal cord injury.
failure of the nervous system causes widespread vasodilation.
there is too much blood to fill a smaller vascular container.
the spinal cord is severed and causes massive hemorrhaging.
front.question: Neurogenic shock occurs when:

cards.back: failure of the nervous system causes widespread vasodilation.
